Falters at times: The claim that "We inherited a broken test" falters at times because it contradicts the fact that a test couldn't be created until the new virus had emerged.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is contradicted by the fact that the test was designed, validated, and deployed by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC).
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption that the test was inherited and not developed by the CDC.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim has an alternative explanation that the slow start of testing was due to tainted reagents and the need to send samples back to the CDC for testing.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that a test couldn't be created until the new virus had emerged.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the extent to which the test was "broken" or ineffective, as it has been changed to address some problems.
Understate: The claim may understate the efforts made by the CDC and other countries in developing and deploying tests for COVID-19.
